ᠬᠠᠲᠤᠨ ᠰᠤᠨᠳᠠᠯᠠᠭᠰᠠᠨ ᠬᠣᠰᠢᠭᠤ ᠰᠢᠦ
ᠬᠠᠨᠠᠭᠠᠷ ᠶᠡᠬᠡ ᠪᠣᠷᠣ ᠲᠣᠬᠣᠢ
ᠬᠥᠬᠡ ᠮᠣᠩᠭᠣᠯ ‍ᠤᠨ ᠥᠯᠥᠭᠡᠢ ᠰᠢᠦ

ᠣᠷᠳᠣᠰ ᠳᠣᠯᠣᠭᠠᠨ ᠬᠣᠰᠢᠭᠤ ᠮᠢᠨᠢ

ᠠᠯᠲᠠᠨ ᠣᠪᠣᠭ᠎ᠠ ᠪᠤᠯᠠᠭ ‍ᠤᠨ ᠰᠢᠯᠢ
ᠠᠪᠠᠢ ᠮᠥᠮᠥ ‍ᠶ᠋ᠢᠨ ᠨᠤᠲᠤᠭ ᠰᠢᠦ
ᠠᠭᠢᠲᠤ ᠲᠣᠯᠣᠭᠠᠢ ᠮᠠᠩᠬᠠᠨ ᠪᠠᠯᠠᠷ
ᠠᠳᠤᠭᠤ ᠮᠠᠯ ‍ᠤᠨ ᠪᠡᠯᠴᠢᠭᠡᠷ ᠰᠢᠦ
ᠠᠢ ᠠᠢ ᠳ᠋ᠠ ᠠᠶ᠋ᠢᠬᠤᠷ ᠬᠠᠢ
ᠡᠪᠦᠭᠡ ᠳᠡᠭᠡᠳᠦ ‍ᠶ᠋ᠢᠨ ᠮᠢᠨᠢ ᠥᠯᠥᠭᠡᠢ ᠪᠣᠯᠤᠭᠰᠠᠨ
ᠣᠷᠳᠣᠰ ᠳᠣᠯᠣᠭᠠᠨ ᠬᠣᠰᠢᠭᠤ ᠮᠢᠨᠢ
ᠠᠢ ᠠᠢ ᠳ᠋ᠠ ᠠᠶ᠋ᠢᠬᠤᠷ ᠬᠠᠢ

item.title: Golden-rule electron transfer rate with a nonequilibrium nuclear initial condition
item.description:
Model: spin-boson

To derive Fermi’s golden rule rate for a nonequilibrium initial state, we use polaron transformation to remove the diagonal linear vibronic couplings (LVC). We start from the usual LVC Hamiltonian
\begin{align} H_{0} & =\left(E_{1}+\omega a^{\dagger}a+c_{1}(a^{\dagger}+a)\right)\left|1\right\rangle \left\langle 1\right|\\ & +\left(E_{2}+\omega a^{\dagger}a+c_{2}(a^{\dagger}+a)\right)\left|2\right\rangle \left\langle 2\right|\\ V & =g_{12}\left|1\right\rangle \left\langle 2\right|+h.c. \end{align}

Here, only a single vibrational mode is used for simplicity of derivation. To include multiple modes, one only needs to replace the single mode term in the conclusion with a sum over all modes.

item.title: Discretizing a continuum using the Gaussian-Legendre quadrature
item.description:
A prototypical model for condensed-phase chemical reactions is the spin-boson model: a two-level spin coupled to a continuum of vibrations (bosons). The spin-boson Hamiltonian is
\[ H = \sigma_x + \sigma_z \otimes \int_0^{x_\mathrm{max}} h(x) \rho(x)(a_{x}^\dagger + a_{x})\mathrm{d}x + \int_0^{x_\mathrm{max}} x\rho(x) a_{x}^\dagger a_{x} \mathrm{d}x \]

Assuming $\rho(x)=1$, to discretize the continuum of bosons, we approximate the integral $\int_0^{x_\mathrm{max}} h(x) (a_{x}^\dagger + a_{x})\mathrm{d}x$ by
\[ \sum_{n=1}^N \left\{ h(x_n) (a_{x_n}^\dagger + a_{x_n})W_n \right\}. \]

item.title: The golden-rule electron transfer rate for a multi-state system
item.description:
Second-order Fermi’s golden rule rate for a two-acceptor electron transfer model

A vibronic Hamiltonian1 of a 3-state electron-transfer system with a single donor and two acceptors is $\hat{H}_0+\hat{V}$.
\begin{align} \hat{H}_{0}&=\hat{h}_{a}\left|a\right\rangle \left\langle a\right|+\hat{h}_{b}\left|b\right\rangle \left\langle b\right|+\hat{h}_{c}\left|c\right\rangle \left\langle c\right|\\ V&=g_{ab}\left|a\right\rangle \left\langle b\right|+g_{ac}\left|a\right\rangle \left\langle c\right|+g_{bc}\left|b\right\rangle \left\langle c\right|+h.c. \end{align}

In this Hamiltonian, $\ket{a}$ is the donor state and $\ket{b}$ and $\ket{c}$ are the two acceptor states. If the electronic couplings among $a$, $b$, and $c$ are small, the electron transfer rate can be calculated by using Fermi’s golden rule. To do this, we turn to the interaction picture and calculate the propagator up to the second order.

item.title: Quantum process tomography and the transfer tensor method for long-time non-Markovian dynamics
item.description:
Motivation

Predicting long-time dynamics from short-time information is a promising way of studying how equilibrium is approached for an open quantum system starting from a non-equilibrium initial condition.

This post discusses one of the prediction methods for long-time open system dynamics, the transfer tensor method (TTM)1. The TTM is based on (i) the Nakajima-Zwanzig equation of an open quantum system [Eq. (1)], and (ii) the assumption that the state of the open system at a time $t$ is barely correlated with the state at $t'$ if $|t-t'|$ is greater than a certain threshold.

item.title: Lanczos tridiagonalization made simple
item.description:
Given a real symmetric matrix $A$, one way to tridigonalize $A$ is the Lanczos procedure which I will introduce below. To transform $A$ into a tridiagonal matrix $T$, we need an orthogonal matrix $U$: $U^\dagger A U = T$ which implies $UT=AU$. Here,
$$ T = \begin{pmatrix} \alpha_1 & \beta_2 & & & \\ \beta_2 & \alpha_2 & \beta_3 & & \\ & \ddots & \ddots & \ddots &\\ & & \beta_{N-1} & \alpha_{N-1} &\beta_{N}\\ & & & \beta_N &\alpha_{N}\\ \end{pmatrix}. $$

item.title: Thermo-field dynamics and mixed initial states
item.description: When simulating the dynamics of open quantum systems, one often assumes a pure initial state of the system part. The validity of the assumption, of course, depends on the experimental realization. In most of the excitation energy transfer experiments, a pure initial state is a faithful representation of the system because the coherent light that excites molecules makes the wave function of the system collapse to a certain state, hence factorizing the system-environment density matrix. The factorized density matrix is $\rho(t=0)=\rho_\mathrm{sys}(0)\otimes\rho_\mathrm{env}(0)$ and the density matrix of the system at time zero (initial state)$\rho_\mathrm{sys}(t=0)$ is a pure-state in this case.

item.title: Jordan Wigner transformation made simple
item.description:
The Jordan-Wigner transformation turns fermionic creation and annihilation operators into a combination of spin operators. I had a hard time understanding how it works until yesterday I came across the notes in this place. The notes list the definitions and the algebra of the “string+spin” operators. The notes themselves, however, still didn’t make me fully understand why things work like this.
But fortunately, I worked out some Kronecker products (or tensor products) of spin operators when I was developing the fishbonett package. The combination of the matrix forms of the Kronecker products and the notes I mentioned hit the spot!

цаг ямар байна? 还是 ямар цаг байна? (什么时候了)

句子

Багш аа, бйд таван chapter сурч, тэгээд нэг Ордос ардин дууны үг сурч болох уу?
Багш аа, чи энэ үгийг яаж дууддаг вэ

《蒙蒙的白雾》转写

Сэнсэн манан

Сэнсэн манан татлаа доо
Сэрүүн цагийн униар (薄雾/尘霭) байна
Шинэхэн (较新的) ханилсанаа бодоход
Сэтгэл минь уярна доо

Хэсэг хэсэг үүлнээс
Хэсэг хур нь орох юм байна
Хэсэг зуурдаа бодоход
Гэртээ суух дургүй доо

为什么词典上的 Гэртээ 是 ᠭᠡᠷ ᠲᠡᠭᠡᠨ。还是说我认错了，不是Гэртээ
Хаврын цагт цуглардаг хамаг шувуухай
春天聚集的成群飞鸟
Хар сэрүүн унахуй цагт харьдаг байлгүй доо
严寒降下时总要南归吧

item.title: About
item.description:
I am a theoretical chemist interested in quantum dynamics and electronic structures of molecules and solids. I can be contacted by email (hanggai.nomin AT gmail.com). The list of my publications is available on the Google Scholar page.

In my free time, I enjoy reading, biking, and ice skating. I also love collecting and listening to Mongolian folk songs. I believe in fostering an inclusive scientific community that values diversity across race, ethnicity, socioeconomic background, disability, gender identity and orientation. By embracing a wide range of perspectives and experiences, we can drive innovation, enhance creativity, and solve complex problems more effectively.
